reviewText: First there's a mess of bone and gristle, wrapped in a chain and uncovered in a Louisiana bayou by Katrina. It's what's left of a black man who was shot down 40 years ago. Maybe he'd been messin' around with a white woman.There's Cherry LeBlanc, a beautiful young girl on the game, sellin' her jellyroll. She'd been cut and eviscerated.There's the dead girl they found stuffed in a barrel a few weeks ago who now has blue crabs crawling all over her. The coroner will only be able to get her out of that barrel in pieces.And there's Dave Robicheaux, a cop in New Iberia, an alcoholic who hasn't yet fallen off the wagon, a Viet Nam vet, a tough man saddled with a conscience and a sense of morality who sometimes does righteous and violent things. "In the ancient world," Dave tells us, "people placed heavy stones on the graves of their dead so their souls would not wander and afflict the living. I always thought this was just the practice of superstitious and primitive people. But I was about to learn that the dead can hover on the edge of our vision with the density and luminosity of mist...and their claim on the earth can be as legitimate and tenacious as our own."Don't let anyone tell you that In the Electric Mist isn't a very good movie, especially if you're fond of James Lee Burke's series of books featuring Robicheaux and the Cajun country of southern Louisiana. Dave (Tommy Lee Jones) is going to find himself searching for a serial killer who needs to cut prostitutes, and he's tormented by what was uncovered in that bayou. When Dave was a little boy he saw the shooting but not who did it. Forty years later he's going to find out who did it and why.Bertrand Tavernier, the director, is going to take us on a journey into bayou Louisiana centered around New Iberia parish where the conditions of life haven't changed much for a lot of people. Along the way we're going to meet all kinds of characters, and this is one of the movie's strengths. Dave may have a good marriage to a strong woman (Mary Steenburgen), but there's also that childhood friend who now is the sociopath Julie "Baby Feet' Balboni (played with great, vicious style by John Goodman). Feets is back in New Iberia because he's backing a movie being filmed nearby. There are aging good ol' boys and blacks who respect Dave but know when to be cautious. There's his daughter Alafair and even a couple of movie stars, Elrod Sykes (Peter Sarsgard) and Kelly Drummond (Kelly Macdonald). There are bayous thick with mosquitoes and trees heavy with moss. The dialogue is pungent and sounds natural. There's even Confederate General John Bell Hood who Dave finds himself talking to now and then. For most of the time, In the Electric Mist is a moody, sometimes vivid, occasionally violent story that has more to do with characters and relationships than murders.This is Tommy Lee Jones' movie. He's in almost every scene. He provides the occasional narrative. His introspective discussions with Hood give us insights to his conflicts (which some of us may or not feel adds to the story). With all the good things about the movie, though, there are three significant weaknesses. First, Jones is too old for the part. He can play tired, seen-it-all types better than most, but he's noticeably older than almost everyone else in the movie. Second, I'm one of those who could easily do without, in the movie as well as in the book, the Confederate specters providing an excuse for Dave's angst and Hood as an excuse for insights into Dave's soul. For me, this is a just a literary device that comes off as unneeded and awkward. Third, the movie attempts to bring the conclusion together too quickly. The knots get tied, but we have no time to satisfactorily understand a couple of the story threads or to savor the conclusion of a movie whose style and characters gave so much pleasure.Well, we can't always get everything we want. What we do get is darn good. The background to the movie, however, might scare us off. Evidently Tavernier and Jones did not see eye to eye as the movie was being filmed. The American producer took Tavernier's cut, chopped off 15 minutes and released the movie direct to DVD in the United States. The movie was released to theaters worldwide elsewhere with Tavernier's 117 minute cut. I've heard one or two critics say that the U.S. DVD release is hard to follow. No it isn't. There is only one part of the story where some useful motivation was evidently hacked up. I'd certainly like to see Tavernier's version. Just stay alert and you'll have few problems.Bernard Tavernier is one of the best directors around. To get a glimpse of his style and variety, tryCoup du Torchon(1981), a supremely mordant and cynical black comedy;D'Artagnan's Daughter(1994), a flashy costume adventure; andLife and Nothing But(1989), a sad and thoughtful film. Tavernier often used Philippe Noiret in his films; it was a great partnership.We'll let Dave have the last word after he's solved the crimes and confronted one of perpetrators. "Have you no mercy, sir?" asks the aging man."No, sir," Dave says. "No, sir, I don't."
summary: Bertrand Tavernier does just fine with Dave Robicheaux. So does Tommy Lee Jones

reviewText: In the Electric Mist marks legendary French filmmaker Bertrand Tavernier's first North American-made motion picture and, based on the troubles he encountered while making it, perhaps his last. Tavernier, a big fan of American crime fiction (he previously adapted Jim Thompson'sPop. 1280intoCoup de Torchon - Criterion Collection), jumped at the chance to bring James Lee Burke's bestselling novelIn the Electric Mist with Confederate Deadto the big screen. However, reports surfaced that Tavernier and the film's star, Tommy Lee Jones, did not get along, and the producers were not happy with the director's version. As a result, the version released on DVD in North America is the producers' cut and not Tavernier's.Tavernier does an excellent job capturing the local color of the area in the scenes where protagonist Dave Robicheaux (Tommy Lee Jones) canvases the locals. The entire film was shot on location and this only enhances the authenticity of the story's setting which is rich in atmosphere - also helped by the liberal use of blues and zydeco music. The cinematography has a textured quality to it that really brings out the lushness of the region.The cast is outstanding with Tommy Lee Jones doing his patented gruff yet savvy lawman, Peter Sarsgaard portraying a boozy actor, and John Goodman as a scene-stealing mobster with a genial facade that barely masks a threatening demeanor. The cast is rounded out by fascinating veteran character actors like Mary Steenburgen, Pruitt Taylor Vince and Ned Beatty.Despite the production and post-production problems that plagued the film, this version is engaging and entertaining but one still wonders what Tavernier's original cut is like.Sadly, the only special features are a theatrical trailer but considering the bad blood between director and the producers this is hardly suprising.
summary: Not the Director's Cut but Still Very Entertaining

There are some that leave out massive details and expect the viewer to fill in, nice effect when done properly (assumes an intelligent audience). Then there is the bulk of the film, edited straight like a melodrama. The voice over narration works for a time, but the technique gets lost and way under used. The cinematography is mostly very well done (there's a few hand held shots that look like reshoots that were poor at best). The dialog is generally clear.The mystery itself is middle of the road. reviewText: Of the modern mystery authors I've read, James Lee Burke is very possibly the most gifted. At moments his prose soars to near-poetry, his insights into humanity's greatness and smallness are impressive, as are his descriptions of the physical world his characters inhabit. "In the Electric Mist With Confederate Dead" is one of my favorite Dave Robicheaux novels, and I was pleased to learn that Tommy Lee Jones was starring in a film version of it. Unfortunately, "In the Electric Mist," as the movie is called, was a little disappoining. The script actually follows the novel very closely, and it was easy to see that Jones, the scriptwriters and director all had an affection (and respect) for the material, which I appreciated. But the movie's faithfulness to the book may have been, I think, part of the problem. There were simply too many characters and scenes in the novel to put into a less than 2-hour film for the finished product to be as effective as it might. Tommy Lee Jones turned in a fine performance as the angst-ridden, but formidable Robicheaux and John Goodman was good as Baby Feet Balboni. (I'd like to have seen more of Mary Steenburgen as Bootsie.) But while many of the scenes worked well, a number of others had an unfinished or glossed-over feel to them -- possibly the result of having to edit a little too heavily to hold down the length of the picture. Despite its flaws, however, "In the Electric Mist" was a noble effort at bringing the work of a top-drawer author together with a top-notch actor, and I salute Jones and company for making it happen. What's more, I hope they try again.

reviewText: Burke's Robicheaux series is interesting for its themes, local color and revelation about the post-chilvaric south.  Burke isn't a great writer; at times he overwrites and may wax eloquent about an old rocking chair on a porch for far longer than necessary. I suspect he hasn't followed Fitzgerald's dictum's of a writer sometimes having to 'kill his babies,' meaning the most elegant, expressive writing in a book may not fit the book and thus must be expunged to lend integrity to it.  That being said, to take all the inner reflections--both emotional and philosophical--and to be able to interweave them with a rather complex narrative is done well in this movie by laconic dialogue that packs a punch, and includes a good use of voice over to get an insight into the protagonist's perspective of his world--one learned over decades as a citizen/observor and law enforcer. You really should read Burke's books first, even one, just to get a grip on his style as well as to understand the idioloic nature of the Louisiana accent and regionalism.  Now I think Tommy Lee Jones does a good job as the lead, but he's not perfect--perhaps because no one could be perfect for to internalize the complexities of a character who has as many sides to him as Hamlet would require a lot of work, and the script simply does not provide that opportunity.  A novel such as this one deserves a longer treatment. I can't imagine it being shorter than 135 minutes--needed to truly get into the world of the story which is the world of a culture both past and present, and a world of a man seeing his culture devolve into decadence and greed.  BTW, note John Sayles as a Jewish movie producer with a bit of added padding and fairly good New Yawk kvetching.

reviewText: There seems to be a lot of disappointment expressed about this film which I find baffling - because even as a complete novice to James Lee Burke's books or the director's past works - I loved it. Disappointingly though, there are precious few extras.Bertrand Tavernier's film isn't a masterpiece for sure, and it's perhaps just a little 'too' in love with its own gumbo and Louisiana scenery, but I found it immensely moving in places - and awkwardly real - especially on the core subject of racism and its still lingering malevolent presence (the title of this review is a rumination by one of the characters on that subject when a dead body from 1965 comes back to haunt him).The film reminded me of John Sayles at his best ("Passion Fish" for instance) - full of heart and great observation - which is high praise indeed...I'd say ignore the so-so reviews and put it high on your rental list. reviewText: Sliding right from a short run (if that) in theatres to DVD, the excellent "In the Electric Mist" is the quintessential "sleeper" film. Based on the James Lee Burke novel "In the Electric Mist with Confederate Dead", the movie finds Burke's Cajun detective Dave Robicheaux once again hot on the trail of a brutal killer. In addition to dealing with the current killing of a young prostitute, Robicheaux must address troubling memories of a murder he witnessed more than 40 years ago as a boy. Throw in for good measure his daily grapple with alcoholism and bizarre visions of conversations with Civil War Confederate General John Bell Hood, who at best gives convoluted advice. Robicheaux (and the viewer) must decide if General Hood's presence in his life is represented by simple reveries brought on by alcohol, or a very real manifestation of the dead coming back to life in order to right a wrong. The latter assertion seems feasable, when one considers the mystical ethic of rural Louisiana where the story unfolds (focus on the last scene of the film for corroboration). Tommy Lee Jones is brilliant as the troubled, flawed, yet highly effective Robicheaux. One can't think of a better choice of actor. Filmed rather beautifully on location, director Tavernier brings the requisite "other-world" atmosphere to the table.

reviewText: This went immediately to dvd after the briefest of theatrical releases.  Fear not.  It's not a hash or a mish-mash.  It's a linear detective story that holds the attention nicely.  Based on the James Lee Burke novel, it offers some of the atmospherics that are the hallmark of Burke's art; it also has some Burkean lines thrown in for good measure.  The casting is (finally) excellent, with Tommy Lee Jones as Dave and other stalwarts like John Goodman, Ned Beatty and the wonderful Buddy Guy.  Those who are unfamiliar with the Robicheaux novels may find themselves struggling to catch up, though there are various exposition points which help fill in the blanks.  The film (like the book) includes scenes in which an LSD-doped Dave begins talking to confederate warriors (here, in particular, John Bell Hood).  This translates to 'magic realism' in the book and here the magic is in Levon Helm's performance as Hood.The Burke novels are so richly textured that the film seems somewhat lean, but it is better to attempt to capture some of the novels' atmosphere than to abandon the attempt.  Jonathan Kellerman has called Burke the Faulkner of crime fiction and here we get a hint of what that means.  The old south and the new converge in a haunted tale in which Dave himself, as a child, played a part.The sets are excellent, particularly the brief post-Katrina glimpse of New Orleans.  Dave's house and bait shop are just as we would imagine them.  So too are the dingy bars on the back roads of New Iberia.  We even get a glimpse of Alafair's three-legged raccoon, Tripod.  Four and a half stars for all Burke fans and at least four for everyone else.  Now read the book.  And then read all the other books.

And, interestingly enough, their appearance has unearthed the ghost of Civil War General General John Bell Hood (Levon Helm) who's acting as an advisor to Dave.Of course, we've got the local troublemakers. Mobster Julie 'Baby Feet' Balboni (John Goodman) is producing the film and might just be killing young women.I admit, often while reading a book, I'm daydreaming my own movies while the pages turn.  I couldn't have asked for a better Dave than Tommy Lee Jones.  He walks the walk and talks the talk as they say.  His supporting cast was excellent as well.  Levon Helm as the General was a touch of genius.  So was Buddy Guy, one of the greatest bluesmen around, as Sam.  I honestly cannot imagine why this film didn't make it to the theatres.  Leonard Maltin called it 'flawed' but I admitted he'd rather see a flawed film that's otherwise well done than a perfect one that just doesn't work.  I didn't see the flaws Mr. Maltin did, but I can say this film definitely did work and I'm glad I purchased it.  Hoping there will be more of Jones as Robicheaux coming soon!Rebecca Kyle, May 2009

reviewText: This film marks the second time novelist James Lee Burke's Cajun detective Dave Robicheaux has been brought to film, the first being Alec Baldwin's remarkably un-Cajun version in "Heaven's Prisoners" back in 1996.  The first film was solid, but it wasn't quite the magic a series needs to launch, nor did it capture critics or audience.  This film doesn't fare much better, but not for the same reasons.James Lee Burke's gift as a writer isn't complex mysteries, but complex characters and a poetic way of describing Louisiana country.  Only one of these gifts (cinematography) tends to resonate well in a film of what we've come to consider "average" length.  So things that propel his novels, like Dave's inner monologues, are mostly cast aside and when they do appear they come off as expositional and flat.Another thing that works against these adaptations is their endings, which is not their fault.  Burke's villains are clear, not very mysterious, and the endings are fairly stock.  They work in the book because the book is mostly a character study of its protagonist.  When applied to these films, however, this tact feels anti-climactic.It also bears pointing out that neither of these films features a key fun element: Dave's right-hand man Clet Purcell (a role many Burke fans thought Goodman would be perfect for), which is in keeping with their respective titles, but does lose some of the magic of better books in the series.  Neither of these books reflects the highest moments of the series overall, so they're hard-pressed to launch the films they become into the stratosphere (and in the case of In the Electric Mist, even into US. theaters).  This adapatation is also hurt by a very unlikely source: the Will Patton-read audiobooks.  Patton does such a phenomenal job capturing the tone and characterizations of Burke's world that it's hard not to see Robicheaux as Patton (who I was bucking for Hollywood to hire, but knew it was unlikely).  I kept peeking around the corners, waiting for that perfect gravely voice to lay it all out for me, but it never came.Electric Mist has plain direction and largely feels like an homage and not an interpretation.  The director's (Bertrand Tavernier doing his first U.S. made film) love of American crime novels is no secret, but parts of this film come off as mild fan fiction:  I love me some Buddy guy, but he can't act.  Levon Helm has some pedigree, but never made his bread and butter off of acting either, and in such an understated role here, it shows.  These are vanity choices by a director enamored of American icons, not American acting.  The people in this film that can act are largely being restrained in the name of understated performances.  Even the big bad guy loses a key scene in the book where he takes a shot at Dave (batter up!) and with little else to hang his menace on, John Goodman just comes off like a storm cloud with no rain in it.  I credit the crew with largely sticking to the book and avoiding knee-jerk Hollywood-isms, like trying to explain the ethnicity of Dave's child or back track through half a dozen books for back story.For all intents and purposes you could watch these films back-to-back and get a nice snapshot of Burke's world, even if the characterizations of the lead are vastly different.  It's interesting to see how different the acting is in roles that cross both films. Some of it is better in the first film (Badja Jola as Batist is way more engaging than Walter Breaux, and Hawthorne James is more menacing than any of the villains in Electric Mist).  Jones is a better Dave.  Mix it up and you'd have had a better film all around.There are great movies that could be made of Burke's books.  Putting more surgical directors on the job would be a good place to start; picking the right book is a close second.  Somewhere between the moodiness of the first film and the clean lines of the second is a great adaptation worthy of launching a series.  And at this point, I'm down with Tommy Lee Jones doing it across the board.  He's got the grit and the soul, even if he does slip into typical Tommy Lee Jones stoicism a lot more than Robicheaux might warrant.  Fans of the books should check it out anyway.
summary: Somewhere between the first and second films is the right film

reviewText: I consider, 'In The Electric Mist With The Confederate Dead,' released in 1993, some of the best of Burke---and his character, Robicheaux. I had the opportunity to listen to the book, way back then, on tape.  Now this was not the 'usual' audio book.  It was complete with eerie sound effects and so expertly done, that my family camped out in the living room, turned out all the lights and we made an evening out of this extraordinary tale.While I don't believe this movie adaptation, 'In the Electric Mist, holds a candle to that first experience, it still provided a great visit, with characters that I came to love, over a decade and a half ago. It was this previous introduction that turned me on to Burke and destined me to become a loyal, forever fan.I'm not sure why, but I've always rather envisioned Robicheaux's character to look something like the dark, craggy, and grumpy, Kinky Friedman. And in real life, he rather does. However, if given a list of potential actors, I would have placed Tommy Lee Jones on the short list, for some of the same physical characteristics. I was able to completely identify him with the role, although I could have used a tad more accent.Robicheaux is an alcoholic, struggling to stay in remission, with many skeletons in his closet, including witnessing a black man being gunned down in the swamps, many years previously---something he chose to remain silent about.  He can no longer remain in denial, when a member of a filming crew working in the swamps, comes across the bones.  In the midst of this event, grizzly murders of prostitutes begin to take place---murders he would love to pin on his sleazy nemesis, the mobster, played by John Goodman.The character who plays Robicheaux's daughter, Alafair, provides some nail-biting moments toward the end of the movie, as well. To digress, I've always loved the way Burke's real daughter is named Alafair and the way he sets up such a bond between Alafair and Robicheaux, in all of his work. I find this sweet and endearing.As Robicheaux begins his investigations, he has hallucinogenic encounters with a troop of Confederate Soldiers, under the famous John Bell Hood. Hood becomes Robicheaux's ghostly sub-conscience, offering insights into seeking and finding truth---an all knowing wisdom, from the grave.The movie is not high on budget and in some respects, it looks almost like a made for TV drama.  However, they still managed to capture the mysterious Cajun atmosphere, making you feel you might just have to start swatting skeeters. I wish there had been more development of the supernatural aspects---the war, the soldiers.  In the book and audio version, this was hair-raisingly spooky, but not so much in this movie.There were a couple of superficial mentions of Katrina, bringing us more up to the moment with Louisiana, which felt a little out of place, because we were dealing with another place and time, with the original story.  Besides, Burke's 'The Tin Roof Blowdown,' is where he excels in describing his beloved New Orleans, post Katrina.I agree, you don't have to have read the book to enjoy this mystery/drama. There's plenty of suspense, reminders of the devastation of war, prejudice and corruption.  It's also contemplative, ensuring we can't run from our demons; that anesthesia through alcohol, won't extinguish the omission of truth, or responsibility.
summary: Stand alone mystery, but enhanced by familiarity of novel.

reviewText: IN THE ELECTRIC MIST, (In the Electric Mist with Confederate Dead), (2008). This 102 minute thriller, helmed by the well-thought of French director Bertrand Tavernier, (Round Midnight) centers on characters created by beloved, bestselling American author of crime dramas, James Lee Burke.  The mystery is set in and around New Orleans, Burke's home, French-speaking turf, after the terrible damage inflicted  on the region in 2005 by Hurricane Katrina.  Principally, it tells us of troubled former New Orleans Police Detective Dave Robicheaux, now a deputy sheriff in neighboring Iberia County. The lead part is fully inhabited by veteran Texas-born actor Tommy Lee Jones, (Men In Black,The Fugitive), who might well have been born to play it, as it was created by the Texas Panhandle-born Burke.The stubborn Robichaux, haunted by his service in the Vietnam War, struggling with a drinking problem, is, as ever, ignoring warnings to leave the local messes alone.  He begins to investigate the possible connections between a series of torture murders of local prostitutes, a 1976 lynching that he witnessed 35 years before as a young boy, and Julie `Baby Feet' Balboni, a notorious New Orleans gangster, played by the popular St. Louis-born John Goodman,(The Big Easy). The Southern-born Mary Steenburgen, (Cross Creek), plays Bootsie, the detective's second wife.  Peter Sarsgaard, (Year of the Dog), plays actor Elrod Sykes, filming locally; Kelly Macdonald, (Intermission), is Sykes' girlfriend Kelly Drummond.  Ned Beatty, (Hear My Song) plays local rich man/bad guy Twinky LeMoyne.  Noted American musician Levon Helm plays long-dead General John Bell Hood, a Civil War stalwart who suddenly starts appearing to and chatting with Robicheaux and Sykes.  Noted American bluesman Buddy Guy plays local bluesman Sam `Hogman' Patin.  Director John Sayles plays Michael Goldman, producer of the picture filming locally. Marco Beltrami created the evocative score; Bruno de Keyzer, the cinematography.  The plot sticks recognizably close to Burke's underlying novel of the same name,In the Electric Mist with Confederate Dead.Jones nails the part of Burke's detective, giving us a rounded performance that shows the complex nature of the character, violent one minute, tender the next.  He is miles better than Alec Baldwin, who was laughably miscast as the detective in HEAVENS PRISONERS.  And it's not a bad movie.  Yet, my understanding is that, although this film was made for theatrical release, it eventually went directly to DVD, which is probably why I, for one, although I am a Burke fan, never knew of its existence until I was informed of it by my Amazon friends.  I think some major structural problems may have caused that outcome.  Any Burke fan will know the detective's best friend, another former NOPD detective, Clete Purcel, overweight, sunburnt, heavy drinker, violent, everlastingly loyal, also native to NO's Irish Channel. Therefore, any Burke fan who has been to the movies a few times, in seeing the cast list before seeing the picture, will expect that Ned Beatty is playing Purcel.  I did.  But, somehow, the Purcel character isn't there, and Beatty is playing one of the heavies.  Also, Goodman has long been associated with The Big Easy, and it was perfectly reasonable to cast him as the gangster in this gritty film.  But Goodman, I believe, is a popular actor, and I suspect people may be uncomfortable with the way he is here treated.  I was.  Both these misjudgments create a film that's disappointing, but I still enjoyed it, as most Burke fans might.
summary: Not a Bad Movie, But Some Serious Misjudgements

reviewText: I found it difficult to initially write a balanced review on ItEM because I felt so connected to this film. To disclaim, I performed Civil War re-enacting for 8 years with the 5th Texas, and my family name matches the main character; Never have seen Robicheaux/Robechaud in any film. So that aside, I just watched a great Tommie Lee Jones film filled with Civil War history (including a great role by Levon Helm playing John Bell Hood) and modern bayou mystery. Also nice to see the Louisiana area get some film money injected into their economy.Plenty of upset people out there about the loss from the book series to film, but since I had not read any of the books, and I appreciate a film that doesn't spell every character out for you - this made for a solid, low-key suspense crime saga. Yes, there is a plethora of characters that pop in and out, obvious story lines not being conveyed in their entire sequence, and personality traits never explained with TLJ's violent/subdued split angles - but it all made (wholeheartedly) for a rewatchable film. Believable performances all around, and I hope to see them all again in more of these (like the successful Jesse Stone/Tom Selleck series). Nitpicking aside from other posters (Yes - there was Texas Cavalry in the Civil War) and the film being too short (I look forward to the other films being made), I hope people give this film a chance.The BD sound was excellent with the DTS, and some of the pans will test your display refresh rate (several sequences of low angles/pointing up with sky backdrops; vehicles driving along ridges, fan boats skimming along the bayou, etc.). Some of the music mix sounded perfect and the 1080p shows our flawed characters' shortcomings in ways I never imagined, including John Goodman in tight swim trunks. There are absolutely no extras to speak of so I could not say this is a 5 star BD release, but definitely worth the purchase.

reviewText: Interesting adaptation of the James Lee Burke novel by the fine French director Bernard Tavernier, starring Tommy Lee Jones. Main problem is the script, which is fairly incoherent -- but then so was the novel. Most interesting thing about Burke's novels is the interior monologue of the main character, Dave Robicheaux -- the action mainly serves as a catalyst for Robicheaux's commentary. In the movie there's minimal voice-over, which ain't the same. One objection: Robicheaux is slipped some LSD in his iced tea and ends up in the hospital after running his truck into a (shallow) ditch and hallucinating up a storm. The hallucinations, and succeeding flashbacks, involve a philosophical dialogue with a dead Civil War general, who'd fought in the area 100 years before. Sorry, Hollywood: those ain't like any LSD hallucinations I ever experienced -- too clean, to coherent. Tavernier does his best with a weak script (& his work is always worth watching -- see "Round Midnight" as the best example). And Tommy Lee Jones is probably the best Dave Robicheaux we can expect. I had hoped for more, but it appears Burke is as hard to adapt as Richard Stark (Payback, Point Blank, The Outfit).
